awd_titl_txt: Encouraging rural and Native American students to participate in interdisciplinary Environmental Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project will increase the number of academically talented, economically disadvantaged students who graduate with interdisciplinary degrees in Environmental Sciences (ES) at the University of Minnesota-Morris (UMM).  The project will include 20 scholars majoring in ES or Geology, Chemistry/Biochemistry, or Physics majors with an ES emphasis.  Student success will be fostered through a well-established academic support program, a dedicated Multi-ethnic Resource staff, academic advising, and peer mentoring.  The project is grounded in the needs of the local and regional community and should help to increase the participation of Native Americans in the pursuit and attainment of STEM degrees. The project will address the national need to increase significantly the number of American scientists with interdisciplinary training.

The project will follow the research-based recommendations of the Society for Advancement of Hispanics/Chicanos and Native Americans in Science 2009-2013 Strategic Plan by focusing on transitions to college life that are critical to the development of underrepresented students and important for the development of all students.  Therefore, it will include (a) active faculty mentoring starting with pre-college registration and encouraged participation in the NSF-IUSE supported summer bridge , (b) cohort activities (shared curriculum, filed trips, and a learning community), and (c) summer research and professional travel opportunities among others.  Formative and summative evaluation will consist of surveys of students' perceptions of the project activities and an analysis of the program outcomes and their impact of those programs on UMM.  Dissemination of the results of evaluation and information about the project in general, will be done at national (American Chemical Society (ACS)) and regional (Midwestern Association of Chemistry Teachers in Liberal Arts Colleges and Great Lakes ACS) conferences and meetings.  The work will be submitted to the Journal of Research in Rural Education and the Journal of American Indian Education.  Moreover, a story suggestion about all University of Minnesota-Morris NSF projects (S-STEM, REU, and IUSE) will be submitted to the American Indian Science and Engineering Society "Winds of Change Magazine."

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the UM Morris S--STEM program was to provide scholarships to encourage Native American and rural, financially disadvantaged students in the interdisciplinary Environmental Sciences. In the original proposal, the project was to identify 20 students (in two 10-student cohorts) and fund those 20 students with S-STEM scholarships for 4 years. In the first year of the UM Morris program however plans changed. 

There were two principle reasons for the change (outlined in annual reports). 1) Student financial need was less than anticipated - the grant originaly funded 75% of unmet need, but in the last two years of the program the grant funded 100% of unmet need (as an adjustment to the pandemic). 2) Additionally, 17 students that were initially funded left the S-STEM program

Over the course of the grant 50 S-STEM scholars were funded.  Of those 50, 20 S-STEM scholars have graduted with a STEM Degree, 6 S-STEM scholars are completing their STEM degree and 24 students left either the university or changed to a non-STEM major.  The 26 succesful S-STEM scholars include 12 Chemistry Majors, 11 Environmental Scence majors, 1 Geology major and 2 Biology majors. Ten of the S-STEM scholars completing their degree were first generation students, three were Hispanic and three were Native American. 

Nineteen of the S-STEM scholars came from rural communities. However, in the last two years of the program students no longer had to be from a rural high school to be eligible for the scholarships (as an additional adjustment to the pandemic).

To facilitate S-STEM scholar success the UMM program focused on advising and building a strong cohort.  The PIs regularly received reports from the faculty of the courses taken by S-STEM students and the PIs were included on any academic alerts. The PIs met regularly with  S-STEM advisees (both individually and as a group).

Of the 20 S-STEM Scholars who have grduated, 8 are employed in STEM fields and two of the S-STEM Scholars are enrolled in Environmental Science Ph.D. Programs (Univ of Colorado, Boulder and Univ. of Minnesota).  The other  graduates are seeking employent in STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 05/25/2023
Modified by: James F P Cotter
